The attacks of January 6 are a symptom of a much deeper problem and the House Republicans who voted against this commission are a part of it. The American people deserve a comprehensive accounting of the threat & a plan that addresses how we as a nation can move forward.
I stood in the House gallery as the mob broke into the Capitol building. There’s no doubt their intent was to undermine our democracy and do harm to those who would uphold it.
It’s a sad day when these Members can’t even stand to support an independent, bipartisan commission focused on the truth.

Today, the House passed H.R. 3233 to establish a commission to address the attack on the Capitol on 1/6 and how we got there as a nation. The vote was bipartisan, but far too many of my Republican colleagues still opposed it.

As a veteran, former federal prosecutor, & now Congresswoman, I’ve taken the oath of office many times. 

Each time it’s meaningful & powerful. 

Opposing a bipartisan, independent commission to examine the events of January 6th betrays the commitments we make in that oath.

Today, I rose on the House floor to speak about why it’s so crucial we establish an independent, bipartisan commission to examine the attack on the Capitol on January 6th. http://pbs.twimg.com/amplify_video_thumb/1395088294724128775/img/Yy2jOQ-DCRFYUg23.jpg https://video.twimg.com/amplify_video/1395088294724128775/vid/500x270/t2N9fAhELgu3Lih_.mp4?tag=14

It also is the perfect example of why we need to establish this commission & take an unflinching look at that day, investigate the security failures & what led to this act of domestic terrorism. 

Without it, we won’t be able to move forward as a nation.

House Republicans ousted Liz Cheney from leadership partly because she refused to sweep the events of 1/6 under the rug. 

Their attempt to whitewash an attack on our democracy and prioritize loyalty to Donald Trump’s “Big Lie” over loyalty to the nation is a disgrace.

Later today, the House will be voting on H.R. 3233, which would create a *bipartisan*, *independent* commission to examine the attack on the Capitol on 1/6. 

I strongly urge my colleagues to vote in favor of this legislation for the sake of our nation.

Tonight, I cast my vote in support of taking the next step to help us understand this attack on our nation — no matter how disturbing or painful that truth may be. I urge the Senate to join the House in passing this bill & starting an honest conversation with the American people.

You’ll see that in so many cases, this bill uses the exact same language on scope, participation & authorities as the 9/11 Commission authorization, which was approved by a Republican-led House and signed into law by a Republican president.

So I'm asking my Republican colleagues in the Senate to do what I did last week: to actually sit down & read this bill. Print a copy of it, as well a copy of the bill from 2002 which created the 9/11 Commission. Put them side-by-side, take out a pen & mark up the similarities.

The attack on the Capitol was one of the darkest days in our history, and to get to the bottom of what led to it & what went wrong on 1/6, we need this independent, bipartisan commission. We can’t let this become a political football — it’s just too important to the country.

The Judiciary works for the American people, not for corporations or special interests. It’s well past time to build a judicial branch that represents the professional and demographic diversity of America. #CourtsMatter

Ketanji Brown Jackson is an exceptionally well-qualified jurist whose credentials and evenhanded approach to the administration of justice make her an ideal candidate for the D.C. Circuit. Her record is one of applying the law to the facts in a thoughtful, fair, impartial manner.

Regina Rodriguez—the daughter of a Mexican-American father and a Japanese-American mother whose family was interned during World War II—has a remarkable breadth of courtroom experience. She'd be the first Asian-American judge on the District Court for the District of Colorado.

From a distinguished career in private practice to serving as a U.S. Magistrate Judge since 2019, Zahid Quraishi is eminently qualified to be a district court judge. Once confirmed, he will be the first American Muslim in U.S. history to serve as an Article III federal judge.

Candace Jackson-Akiwumi would bring much needed diversity to the Seventh Circuit, which currently has no judges of color. She has worked on civil matters in private practice & spent ten years as a federal public defender—a record that reflects a deep commitment to equal justice.

Widely praised for his impeccable qualifications and character, Julien Neals's distinguished career earned him a voice vote out of Committee in 2015 after his initial nomination to the NJ District Court. He'll be ready to take on the challenges of the District Court from day one.
